definition: to apply to/to put into (practice etc)/to put to (a test, a vote etc)
to pay/to hand over to/classifier for pairs or sets of things
to put into practice/to carry out (idiom)

sentences.english: However, this is very difficult to apply in practice on actual projects.
sentences.chinese: 但是在实际的项目中，这是非常难于付诸实践的。

sentences.english: And through prayer, God helps me put into practice what I learn.
sentences.chinese: 借着祷告，上帝帮助我把所明白的东西付诸实践。

sentences.english: Another year and another dream had been eaten by the locusts .
sentences.chinese: 又一年，又一个好梦因蝗虫而付诸流水了。

sentences.english: But now we have to execute, not only say the words.
sentences.chinese: 但我们要付诸实施，不能停留在口头上。

sentences.english: Let us put his ideas into practice.
sentences.chinese: 让我们把他的思想付诸实践。

sentences.english: We just need to put into practice what we already know. Be a doer of the Word.
sentences.chinese: 我们只需将所知付诸实践，做个真正的实干家。

sentences.english: Let’s conclude with some tips for putting this idea into practice.
sentences.chinese: 让我们来总结一些把这个想法付诸实践的小提示吧。

sentences.english: To get anywhere, you need to be constructive. You have to make an effort.
sentences.chinese: 不论走到何种地步，都要积极筹划，付诸努力。

sentences.english: But no action has been taken on it.
She's determined to put her ideas into practice.
sentences.chinese: 她已决心要把自己的想法付诸于实践。

sentences.english: Li-ion battery system is a successful example for putting the intercalation theory into practice.
sentences.chinese: 锂离子电池为将嵌入理论付诸实践的一个成功的实例。

sentences.english: You need more practice before you can play for our team.
sentences.chinese: 我们必须将计划付诸实行。

sentences.english: Otherwise, our efforts for all these years will be in vain.
sentences.chinese: 否则，我们这些年的努力都将付诸流水。

sentences.english: She gets a chance to act out her fantasies.
sentences.chinese: 她得到了一个把她的怪念头付诸行动的机会。

sentences.english: But that’s hard advice to put into practice sometimes.
sentences.chinese: 可是有时候这是个难以付诸实施的建议。

sentences.english: And so you had some councils doing this.

definition: to put into practice/to carry out (idiom)
to appeal (to reason, sentiment, charity etc)/to resort to (a course of action)
practice/to put into practice/to live up to (a promise)/to carry out (a project)

lit. military tactics on paper (idiom)/fig. theoretical discussion that is worse than useless in practice/armchair strategist/idle theorizing/cf Zhao Kuo 趙括|赵括 leading an army of 400,000 to total annihilation at battle of Changping 長平之戰|长平之战 in 260 BC
tied up in a bundle on a high shelf/to put sth on the back burner/no longer a high priority
to put pen to paper/pen mark
to blot out at one stroke/to reject out of hand/to deny without a hearing
to give up halfway (idiom); leave sth unfinished
